Posts.Content: I think we've all felt anxious, i know i had a panic attack after my MRI which then caused anxiety for other scans i needed to go for, but looking back i think i had just become overwhelmed with all that was going on. Talking on here has helped me lost, always someone to give advice. Have you tired ringing your macmillan nurse,when ever i speak to mine they are amazing, no rushing to get you off the phone and lots of listening and advice about things. Maybe give them a go. But also feel free to rant, cry and celebrate with us all xx Big Hugs for you xxx
Posts.Title: The waiting is getting me down

Posts.Content: NiceCuppa there are no idiots here and that includes you.  This is not your fault.  You feel like this and I think anyone who had care like you’ve had would feel the same.  I wish I could scoop you up and squeeze you tight and tell you everything is going to be alright.  You will not be like this all the way through your chemo the 2 are so very different, anyway who is she to tell you how you’re going to be, has she gone through it herself? I very much doubt it or she wouldn’t speak to you the way she has.  I had a few times when I thought I couldn’t do it any more and even at one point told my kids that I wasn’t going to carry on with my chemo. So don’t be too hard on yourself we’ve all felt like you feel at some point in our treatment.  Try not to think about it over the weekend, get plenty of rest and do something you love doing xxx
Posts.Title: Fuming with comment from nurse in Chemo unit

Posts.Content: NiceCuppa i think you need a hug first  You are not being over sensitive, you are allowed to feel poopy and to be honest with you a good cry does you good, now let's get those pieces put back together. When she asked what did you use to do you should have told her you was a belly dancer, and watched the look on her face. Is there anything we can do to help? Apart from me organising a mini bus to pick a few of us up to come with you next time?  In time all this will be a distant memory, although that doesn't help when you are stuck in the middle of it. You have done so well so far and you will continue to do so.  Have you had chance to speak to your oncologist? I was neutropenic after my first docetaxel and they thought i had sepsis but luckily i didn't. But when i spoke to my oncologist he lowered the dose of my remaining treatments and i was ok then, i also put myself into isolation the week after treatment to avoid any bugs being brought into the house. Keep talking to us. we will help you get through this xxx lots of love xxx
Posts.Title: Fuming with comment from nurse in Chemo unit

Posts.Content: Mrs50 i had the injections with every chemo treatment, my nurse told me to take them out of the fridge half an hour before i did them as otherwise it tends to sting when you do them. She also said to do them just before bed so if there were any aches and pains i would sleep through them. I worried about doing the injections but not once did they hurt, whether this is because of the large amount of fat i have to inject into whoops!!! but they were lots easier than i thought. I also never missed any chemo treatments either even after i'd been into hospital after my 3rd with no blood count at all it was built back up in time for my 4th treatment.

Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Morning everyone, RumCat Hope your first chemotherapy has gone ok today and you're feeling ok, make sure you take whatever medication you have been given even if you feel ok. Also at any time if you need advice ring the emergency number you will have been given, do not think that they will automatically send you to hospital because they don't but can give advice to make it easier. Plus don't forget we're here for advice and support xx good luck xx Daisydoo38 How poopy that you had to spend a night in hotel NHS Hope the SEs are easing now and you're feeling better. Hopefully they will sort your medication out so it won't happen next time. couttleberry good to see you, i found i got more and more tired as treatment went on, remind yourself what the chemo is doing, it might be the devil in disguise but in time it will help to make you better. I had 3x docetaxel and felt the same as you when i switched from FEC to Docetaxel, so anything that is worrying you give me a shout, either on here or send me a message. I did find myself more tired but NO sickness or nausea. Sorry cant help with fitting you a cooker before christmas or fix your roof so hopefully someone who knows what they're doing will sort that for you.  Good to know your getting use to no hair, mine started growing back after my second docetaxel and its amazing how fast it grows, still not enough to go out without a hat but i won't be long before i can. As for regulating body temperature hat on cos i'm cold, hat off because i'm melting, hat back on because i'm cold, its a vicious circle and don't even mention the night sweats, cover on, covers off lol  Karen 234 We will have none of that you have failed!!! (i have my mummy voice on can you tell) you have completed what is necessary and it was the professionals who said you didn't need it anymore and not you saying you didn't want it. You're not the first and won't be the last to to have treatment shortened. So we'll have a Congratulations and well done on completing your chemotherapy  Birdsoafeather Well done on hitting the half way mark. Have you thought of having ice lollies when struggling with drinking?? i also these were nice when taste buds had decided to take a holiday lol i finished my chemo 6 weeks ago today, i had 3 x docetaxel so anything you want to know give me a shout. Hello Kpr2018 Hope you're first appointment went ok and you got lots of questions answered. Worrying is natural we've all been there but ask here if there is anything you think we can help you with. No question is a silly one. I've been where you are i am now 6 weeks on from the end of my chemotherapy and it worked a treat, i was originally told the aim of the chemo was to shrink the 6cm tumor, i had an MRI and was told last week that NO cancer cells are showing so it was worth every minute. So give me a shout if there is anything i can help you with. Remember you are all amazing, even when you feel you aren't xxx

Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: TheScriptFan sneaks in hoping no one realises shes finished her chemotherapy but misses her friends so much shes hiding in the corner and hoping no one notices shes here Whitby mine started falling out the same time as yours day 13 after my first FEC, because my hair was long i think it felt like more was falling out than actually was, i didn't do anything to my hair until 2 days before treatment 2 when i just had it cut to shoulder length. Although it was falling out it didn't look too bad, but the day after my second chemotherapy i washed my hair and the bottom of the bath was covered, i wrapped my head in a towel and rung my sister in floods of tears asking her if she'd come and take the towel off my head. She did and it had all fallen out at the top but i still had quite a bit around the back, i looked like a monk, i still hung onto it until 5 days after my 2nd FEC why?? i have no idea, and i was a cow bag to everyone. So on the Sunday after my second treatment my sister came and shaved my head with the clippers on a number one, with the guard on to make sure it didn't cut my head. The relief was unbelievable, i wish i'd done it sooner instead of putting myself through the waiting for the inevitable. My hair started growing back after my 5th treatment (docetaxel) and now 4 weeks after chemo has finished i have about 2cm of hair. Funny i have got use to not having any, and the quick showers are brill, shower before bed without having to dry your hair. I didn't actually lose all my hair always had a strip along the back that didn't fall out, also i haven't lost all of my eye brows or eye lashes but there aren't many left. AnnJac i'm so glad you're finally feeling better, enjoy the time you sure do deserve it. Hope everyone is doing ok and coping well,

Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Any of you struggling with your chemo just wanted to say keep at it, it really is worth it. Today i went to see my specialist who told me that there was NO cancer visible on my MRI :) the chemo definitely did its job. The ultrasound lady was gobsmacked at how large my lymph nodes were at the beginning to how small they are now, she said "It must be a christmas miracle" lol  So when you're feeling poopy keep in mind that its doing what it should be doing.I know everyone won't have the same result as me but chemo definitely makes a difference. I know easier said than done but the happy tears today from both me and especially my mum who is 70 today it was well worth it. Keep kicking butt xxx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hiya RumCat i also found it a bit of a rollercoaster ride before i started my chemo, i think everything seems to happen so fast you're left in a whirl. I wasn't assigned a breast cancer nurse i was just given the number of the breast care clinic and one of the nurses ring me back. They are all amazing and never make you feel like you are pestering or wasting their time. I don't know about your hospital but my breast care nurse is different to my oncology nurse, i have been able to ring my breast care nurse from the start where as my oncology nurse i only rung while having chemotherapy. I know it's scary but try not to be, it really isn't as scary as you think and when you've had your first chemo on Tuesday you'll think, is that it. We'll all be here waiting to hear how its gone and ready to support you in whichever way we can. If you think of any questions write them down and take them with you so you don't forget what to ask. But if there are any questions you forget to ask, you can ask at the chemo clinic on Tuesday or give us a shout and there will probably someone who can help you out.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hiya Jo36 i finished my chemotherapy 5 weeks ago and the fatigue and exhaustion has been awful. Its hard to explain but someone explained it spot on, its not feeling tired as wanting to go to sleep, its no energy to do anything. I have felt better over the last couple of days, still not 100% but definitely better than i was. As my breast care nurse told me " Just because you have finished chemo doesn't mean it isn't still working in your body" so don't push yourself too much your energy will come back just give it time. And thanks for the congratulations!! My energy better be back before baby comes i think i'll need it. My tastebuds came back towards the end of week 3 beginning of week 4 its wonderful.

Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Tigermum i had lots of SEs with docetaxel but what you have to remember is just because it happens to one person doesn't mean it will happen to you. The thing you need to keep a check on with docetaxel is your immune system, it kicked mine down big time. So make sure you take your temperature regularly. I use to wake up and often felt dizzy i wondered if this was low blood sugar so had real sugar (rather than sweetener) on my cereal and it seemed to work. It made me feel a lot more tired and exhausted than FEC ever did. Be careful with paracetamol that it doesn't hide the symptoms if you have got any kind of infection. I had no sickness with docetaxel just felt tired most of the time, no taste buds and my nails started lifting from my nail bed (but i haven't heard the nail thing happening to many people)  I have finished my chemo now and finally started having a bit more energy and my tastebuds are back to normal :O)
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Sept78 i had the same problem, i described it as it felt like my vein was too short for my arm and when i tried to straighten it it pulled on the vein. I was a bit luckier than you as i only had 3 FEC so after i'd had 2 in my right arm i had the rest of my chemo into my left arm 1 x FEC 3 X Docetaxel so didn't have the same problem with my left. Speak to your chemo nurse see if they can do anything for you. I was given some cream called Hirudoid cream to rub onto the affects vein which eased it plus i found an cold wheat bag helped too. You can visibly see the vein in my right arm now, it doesn't hurt at all anymore and no longer pulls but you can see where it is and feel it under the skin. I was told FEC can harden your veins and i'm guessing this is what happened. There are lots of people on here who have had a PICC line in i'm sure they'll be along soon, maybe worth a try as i've been told its lots easier than having a cannula every time. And NEVER apologise for moaning, we all do it and thats what we're here for xxxx

Posts.Content: Hello  Janet12 no question is a trivial one if its causing you any kind of anxiety so glad you asked. I've been in hospital twice now and both times i left my mobile phone in my suitcase in my room, and it was still there when i came back. In fact yesterday the nurse went into my suitcase to get me it out when i got back to my room. Also like someone else has mentioned i went down to theatre in my dressing gown, slippers and glasses. These were put in a bag with my name on and were in my room with me when i woke up. So maybe if you don't want to leave valuables in your room you could put them in your dressing gown pocket and they would be kept with you. I was also told that if i wanted my mobile locked up to ask a nurse and they would lock it in the medical cabinet and keep it safe until i got back, so lots of options.

Posts.Title: Hormone positive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hiya mariana you have come to the right place. We are like one big family here, there is always someone here to support you, give you advice and they even make us laugh. I know you are on your own but to be honest people who haven't had cancer themselves don't always get you anyway. It can be very lonely but coming here talking to people who have been, are going through or starting treatment the same as you really really helps. I live on my own with my grown up son, i have had times where i've felt so alone but come on here for an hour or so and don't feel so lonely anymore. Don't worry about coming and ranting, moaning, crying we've all been there and no one judges anyone.Meetups are also arranged all over the country so in no time you'll make some new friends. I live in Yorkshire and i now have a good friend who i met through here who lives in Barcelona. We text each other often and when i was going through the hardest part of my treatment she was there for me, i plan on going to visit her in May. We are all here for you, if you're having chemotherapy Leolady56 starts a new post every month which is fantastic because people can go through it together. And in time you'll go from the lady who is asking for advice to the lady who is giving advice. It feels amazing knowing you're helping others. Big Hugs for you, And don't forget we are all here for you.

Posts.Title: new patient

Posts.Content: Hiya sarah316 we've all felt the way you are feeling its quite "normal"  I found that once my treatment started everything seemed so much easier. I dealt with it by taking it a step at a time. So concentrate on your lumpectomy, try not to think any further in front. Once the lumpectomy is over with and you have recovered then concentrate on your chemotherapy, but only one treatment at a time. Once you know what chemotherapy you will be having come and ask us all about it. There will be someone here who will have had the same as you. They can tell you what to expect and how to deal with the SEs etc. How old are your children? My godson who is 2 has dealt with Auntie Shelley losing her hair really well, we told him that the medicine that was going to make me better makes my hair fall out, but it doesn't matter because it will grow back. They will get use to mum with no hair. And you'll get use to it too. Before i lost my hair it was the worse thing that could happen. Once it had gone it was such a big relief and now it doesn't really bother my much at all. Believe it or not most of the time you will LOOK well, in fact if you're like me you'll get fed up of people telling you how well you look. So even though you may feel unwell sometimes your kids won't necessarily know you are. Come talk to us this place is amazing no question is a silly one and things that seem like big problems are often halved or are no longer a problem once you've spoke to someone about it.

Posts.Title: one step forwards....

Posts.Content: Hello LH60 i found myself in exactly the same situation as you and its a tricky one.  I can't advise you what to do, just like no one could advise me, because at the end of the day you have to make the decision but also remember it was the right decision at the time. Can i also say that my cancer was triple negative and not hormonal like yours. I had a lumpectomy in January and when the results came back i didn't have clear margins, there was a 1mm cancer showing and a DCIS. I was told i could have another lumpectomy or go straight for a mastectomy. After hours of wondering what was best, i decided to go for another lumpectomy. I was absolutely devastated when i again didn't get clear margins. They found another 5mm and more DCIS. Within 2 weeks i was in having a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. I am 6 weeks past that now and last week was given the all clear. When i think back i'm not sure i would have done it any different because if i could have kept my original boob it would have been worth it. The only thing i feel i have lost is time getting rid of it.  Results after my mastectomy were it was the best thing because they found more cancer, more DCIS and a lymph node with cancer in it which now have all gone.  But please remember we are all different and all treatments work differently for different people. You need to decide whats best for you, not anyone else and once you've made that decision remember it was the best one. Please talk to me if i can help with any questions at all.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or re- excision?

Posts.Content: LH60 have you not been offered any kind of reconstruction if you chose to have another lumpectomy? I was told that if my second would have been successful my surgeon would have used the fat just under my boobs, my middle tyre, to fill in the space left from the lumpectomy.  I had an immediate reconstruction after my mastectomy using the muscle from my back. One of my biggest fears was to wake up with a boob missing, silly when you think all we have been through but thats just how i felt. Straight after the mastectomy my boob didn't hurt at all, they cut through the nerves so its a bit numb. I did have a bit of pain in my back from where they had taken the muscle but it wasn't anything that wasn't solved with pain killers. It felt more stiff, someone described it to me as if you have a broom handle fastened to your back, you want to bend but you can't not for the couple weeks anyway. The drain was more of a nuisance than anything else. I'm happy with the results although my new boob is smaller than my old boob but this isn't noticeable when i'm dressed. I go back and see my consultant again in November to discuss making them even.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy or re- excision?

Posts.Content: I use to use diprobase cream because i had eczema on my face, it was great stuff and worked a treat, if you get it from your doctor you can get it in a big pump container too.

Posts.Content: Hi lulupop once i had finished my chemotherapy i was told my MRI clear and showed no cancer, i was so relieved and thought the same as you its over with, lumpectomy, radiotherapy and back to work.  Went for my lumpectomy and when the results came back i was told there was a 1 mm cancer cell showing and a DCIS. So i was asked if i wanted another lumpectomy or a mastectomy. It hit my like ton of bricks, if anything it hit me harder than finding out it had the cancer to start with. My daughter was a little annoyed and asked why they had told me no cancer was showing on my MRI making me believe it had all gone.  I am now waiting for the results from my second lumpectomy, if it had all gone to plan i would have been going back to work next week.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed last week

Posts.Content: Hello Architect Sorry to hear your wife is having such a bad time. Have you mentioned the sickness to her oncologist? or even rung the breast care nurse? I'm not saying your GP doesn't know what they are talking about but maybe if you speak to the people who specialise in chemo they might know better. The breast care nurses are there for you all the time so they won't mind you worrying, and might be able to advise the best action to take. I wasn't physically sick with EC but felt terribly sick, i found that if i didn't eat the sicky feeling was worse. I found eating little but often even if i wasn't hungry helped. Hope they soon get your wife sorted. Shes lucky she has such a caring husband to take care of her.

Posts.Content: My nails were fine until i started on docetaxel. Then they lifted from the nailbed, it felt like they were all going to fall off so for about 2 weeks i walked about with plasters wrapped around my finger ends. I had shellac on at the time so couldnt see what was happening but i could feel it, they felt tender but again the plasters helped. Once i took the shellac off i could see where the nail had lifted from,  None actually fell off and eventually grew out, i can't have shellac on at the minute due to being in and out of hospital for lumpectomy etc so not had any put back on, my nails are a bit flaky and brittle but i think once i can have shellac on again they'll be fine and stop breaking. I found the side i had the most chemo in was affected more than the other. Now my big toe is a totally different story, no others just my big toe on my right foot, 4 months post chemo and i am waiting for it to drop off, hopefully it won't and it will just grow out like my finger nails.

Posts.Title: The Fear is starting to hit now

Posts.Content: Morning pippi Sorry to hear you've had this chuffing thing twice. I can't really help with how to stop worrying, i still haven't got the all clear from my first cancer and already worry about it coming back.  Have you thought of some kind of counselling? i know MacMillan do it and i'm sure your doctor would refer you if you went and spoke to them. I've had counselling in the past (not cancer related) and it worked. They help you to look at things in a different way.  We have to try and live our lives and not let this stupid bloody illness take over but its so much easier said than done. I also think that unless you've been through it yourself, no one, no matter how much you talk to them will ever understand. I know i didn't understand until i got it myself. Just know there are always people here to talk to, don't ever feel like you're on your own xxx

My favourite one is "But you look so well"  If i had a pound for everytime someone said that i wouldn't have to go back to work. I use to say thank you then eventually started saying "I might look well today but you should have seen me yesterday" or "Looks can be deceiving" I don't want sympathy from people but on the other had i don't want them thinking the last 6 months for me has been a walk in the park, far from. Another when your hair is falling out, "Don't worry it will grow back" erm that doesn't help at the time and the "It suits you" WHAT!!!! then why haven't i had a bald head all my life lol  You have to laugh or you'd cry xxx

Maybe give her a ring if you think it will help, they're lovely and more than happy to help. Also ask away on here, you can do this and you will because one thing we all have is inner strength that we never knew we had.  Make sure you talk to us, rant, cry, moan and we sometimes have a laugh. Posts.Title: Waiting, waiting, waiting

Posts.Content: Hiya Allypops i've had something similar but its not in my breast but my right hand and arm. After my second FEC the vein i had the chemo into became really sore,felt like it was bruised and it went right up my arm. The only way i could describe it was that my vein pulled if i tried to straighten my arm, this started the second week after treatment. When i held my arm straight you could see the vein through my skin all the way up my arm, The vein looked dark and felt really tight. I ended up in hospital with an infection, not related to the vein, but i mentioned it to the doctor and he said that the chemo i was having could irritate the veins. It wore off after a week but when i had my 3rd treatment (i asked for it in my left hand due to the pain in my right last time) the second week my right hand and arm felt sore again. I took it that its because the vein is already irritated so when i had the chemo again and it got round to the vein it caused more irritation. Its still sore and i have my 4th chemo on Tuesday. When i straighten my arm the vein becomes tight and i can see where it is under my skin. They did give me cream to ease the bruising pain but i found a cold rice bag helped the most.
Posts.Title: Swelling and bruising during chemo (neo- adjuvant)

Posts.Content: Hello Annecra like you say "Who’d have thought we’d end up being part of this community". Not one any of us would have chosen but in the circumstances its the best place to be. Its an amazing place full of support and advice. Wow!!! You have been in a bit of a whirlwind, not even a week to wait for your op, thats fast. Which op did you have? Was it a lumpectomy or a mastectomy? Was you given exercises to do after your op? I know i was with both my lumpectomy and my mastectomy. They are to prevent your arm and shoulder getting stiff. If you have make sure you do them they really work. If you haven't then ring your breast care nurse and tell her you haven't been given any exercises to do. 2-3 weeks seems about right for the wait for results, i know i waited for 4 weeks for some of mine.  Please have a look around and ask any questions you may need the answers to, there are lots of us around to show you the ropes, offer advice and give you all the support you need. Take it easy remember you have had surgery even if you feel well, look after yourself.

Posts.Title: Just joined :)

Posts.Content: A friend of mine put this on facebook this morning. It made me cry because it makes sense of some of the feelings i've had while kicking this thing, so if you're struggling at all please read it and understand its ok to not be ok sometimes. If the mountain seems too big today then climb a hill instead if the morning brings you sadness it's ok to stay in bed if the day ahead weighs heavy and your plans feel like a curse there's no shame in rearranging don't make yourself feel worse if a shower stings like needles and a bath feels like you'll drown if you haven't washed your hair for days don't throw away your crown a day is not a lifetime a rest is not defeat don't think of it as failure just a quiet, kind retreat it's ok to take a moment from an anxious, fractured mind the world will not stop turning while you get realigned the mountain will still be there when you want to try again you can climb it in your own time just love yourself till then Lots of love and hugs to you all xxx

Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi howaboutthat i had a mastectomy 4 1/2 weeks ago with immediate reconstruction using muscle from my back. I spent 5 days in hospital but this was because they wanted to be sure there was no problems with the skin and muscle. I wasn't allowed to lift my arm above my shoulder for 4 weeks and this week started exercises to get muscles working again. I am back driving and doing things i did before, although being cautious until i know what i can do. Had hardly any pain more of an ache, which was easily resolved with ibuprofen or paracetamol. The reason i chose a reconstruction with my back muscles was because they don't actually disconnect the blood vessels from your body they just move the muscle round to the front.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and reconstruction advise

Posts.Content: VJRPBraehead and Ruby1970 can i first welcome you both to the community none of want to be a member of but under the circumstances the best community. This place is fantastic for support and advice. I know because the lovely people here got me through the last year and continue to do so even though i now have the all clear. I think everyone struggles when they first get told, after all its not something any of us expect to happen. Just know we have all been where you are now. Everyone struggles but i found once i go chatting to people who "Got Me" because they were or had been through the same it made it easier. Read my profile and see that i had some DCIS but now they are gone, i am now cancer free and you will be too. My advice is take each step at a time, write down any questions you have and take them to appointments, because if you're like me the minute you get in there your mind will go blank. You will also be given a breast care nurse, most of them are worth their weight in gold and will be there for you throughout and long after all this. So use them, ring if you are unsure about anything or want any answers. Coming here you will meet people who have been or are going through what you are, and before you know it you'll be the ones giving advice to others. Like Leolady56 said, no question is a silly one, believe me i've asked some in my time here but there is always someone who comes along and understands or has been through the same.  Don't put yourself under too much pressure, its ok to have days you feel poopy but don't let them out weight the days you feel strong and you've got this sorted. Once  you have a treatment plan and understand what is going to happen you'll feel better and more in control.  We'll be beside you every step of the way climbing that mountain don't you worry and we'll be there cheering you on when you reach the top. Keep talking to us ladies xxx

Posts.Content: Missmeow1983 try to keep positive, i know it's easier said than done but don't put yourself through the worry until you know for sure there is something to worry about. I cried and i worried to be told 11 days later it was nothing, i was so cross with myself for thinking the worst. But i understand why we do because i'm sure none of ever thought we would be in this situation. I will keep my fingers crossed tight let us know how you get one. Big Hugs xx
Posts.Title: D day - Get my results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hiya Optimistic thanks for your response. Would you believe that since i wrote this a neighbour called to show me her new grandson and she told me about her Aunt who had her reconstruction done with her back muscle. She said it was amazing and that you can't tell the difference at all. So fingers crossed. To answer your question, the reason i chose this one over the others was: 1. A implant will stay the same whatever. So if i lose weight my own boob will get smaller but the implant will stay the same size, same if i put on weight. So ruled that one out.  2. With a diep the tissue is disconnected from the body, the blood vessels are then reattached through micro surgery. This can sometimes cause complications due to the small vessels.The wound to remove the tissue is normally bigger than the wound to move the tissue in a latissimus dorsi flap procedure (using back muscle) so will take longer to heal.  3. In a latissimus dorsi flap procedure, the muscle/fat is not disconnected from the body so no problems reconnecting blood supply as it never disconnected. 4. The scar on your back is hidden by your bra and not as big as with a diep. 5. It looks more natural than an implant. The only negative is i have been told i will have some weakness in my arm, but as it is my left side and i am right handed i can't see it causing me much problem. I'll let you know how it goes xx

Posts.Content: I didn't cry until 2 weeks after my diagnosis, and then i cried because i was scared of the MRI not because of the cancer. I think once i'd got diagnosed i just wanted to get on with it and get rid so didn't cry. My philosophy was and still is, being sad won't make it go away and by making me laugh and smile it will make this awful time so much easier. Saying that i have cried, and i remember my mum saying, it is ok to cry. There are no hard and fast rules on when you should cry or how often, everyone's different. I know this place helps a lot, i came on here one morning when i was having a really bad day,  i wrote a post ranting and crying. Within no time people had replied and they helped me feel so much better. So when ever you need to talk, talk away. And if you don't want to do it on here in public there is a private message option, just send me a message and i'll listen and help all i can xxx

Posts.Title: **** July Breast Cancer Chemo Club ****

Posts.Content: I was lucky enough for my hospital to give me one with my chemo pack. I had my first chemo yesterday sickness has been a killer but feeling much better now and will speak to my doc about more anti sickness pills. I find if i do my temperature under my arm it is lower than if i do it under my tongue x
Posts.Title: Temperature

Posts.Content: Morning daisyjake first things first :O)  I guess i'm lucky i have always had every faith in my team so never worried about times between procedures. I'm sure your surgeon wouldn't leave you until the 11th if they didn't think it was fine to do so. At the end of the day they are there to make you better, so try not to worry too much, i know its easier said than done.  My lump was 6cm when i was first diagnosed with some lymph nodes involved. I was lucky though never had any pain, in fact i didn't even know it was there. As for the pain have you tired a hot water bottle, i find sometimes heat works. Don't have it too hot though you don't want to be burning yourself.  Keep talking to us and i hope you have as good a day as you possibly can xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosis yesterday

Posts.Content: Janet14 once you have your plan and start treatment it will be easier, i think of it this way, it is what it is and worrying about it won't make it go away it will just make it more difficult to cope with, so grab the bull by the horns and lets get this kicked xx It's not easy but it is doeable and you will do this xxx
Posts.Title: The agony of waiting...

Posts.Content: Morning Janet14 we have all been where you are and we all felt in some way the same. The waiting is the worse part of all of this poopiness as your mind takes over and always thinks of the worse case scenario. The aches and pains everywhere, you will find lots of us had them and continue to do so. I even got that when i had a headache i was asking, is it more painful than normal, has it lasted longer than usual. I felt the same as you, i walked into the clinic thinking i was perfectly healthy to be told i had breast cancer, but How?? I don't feel poorly, but thats how sneaky the little b***er is.  Don't struggle, talk to us, thats what we are here for, i have been here since the day i found out and the place has offered me so much support its amazing. You might think but they're only people online but they have got me through some of my hardest day and i have shared my best days with them too. Before you know it you're giving out advice too and that feels just if not even more amazing knowing you have helped someone else. As for the replying, if you click reply it just adds your post to the bottom. You can tag people which will then highlight their name and notify them that someone has sent a reply to them. To do that you type @ then start typing their name, it will appear in a drop down thing and click on their name and it will show.  You'll be an expert in no time, keep talking to us, big hugs for you xxx
Posts.Title: The agony of waiting...

Posts.Content: Hiya sunshinesuzie Welcome to the group no one wants to join, but its the best group to be a member of in the circumstances. Who on earth told you that you'd feel invincible, i use to describe FEC as first week poopy, second week not so poopy and week 3 felt great just in time for it to start again. Don't worry about what you eat, just eat what you fancy. I lived on Chicken soup and cheesy garlic bread lol then on the last week i use to make up for it.  One bit of advice i would give you is, eat little and often even if you don't feel hungry. This use to stop me from feeling so sick.
Posts.Title: Eating during FEC first week

Posts.Content: Happy Easter to you too Lellyv Hope you have a lovely weekend, What a lovely post  xx
Posts.Title: Nothing to do with cancer

Posts.Content: Lellyv you are no baby!!! I wish I’d had a picc line now. My veins are done and everyone struggles to take blood or fit me with a cannula. So now I am frightened of cannulas and blood tests because it such a big thing.  i have found with most of this pooppiness that nothing is ever as bad as you think it is going to be. The waiting and the worrying are the worse bits.  My weekend is going to be brill, my daughter is on her way home with her baby in her belly and what she doesn’t know if her university friend is coming too, I can’t wait to see her face. So a weekend with my kids nothing better xxx  you need any advice or a chat give me a shout xxx
Posts.Title: Nothing to do with cancer

Posts.Content: Morning Helsjw We've all been there, so talk to us, tell us your worries and your concerns and someone always appears who have been there, or going through the same. I found talking about things on here really helped. Time standing still, yes it does but it will soon get moving again, once you get your treatment plan you can concentrate on kicking butt, the best advice i was given is take each step at a time and make sure you get plenty of rest.  But talk to us, rant to us, and believe it or not this place will make you smile and even laugh. Lots of love you can do this!!!
Posts.Title: Morning after diagnosis.....

Posts.Content: Hiya Grandmasgirls i have stage 3 triple negative breast cancer. I had a lumpectomy at the beginning of January but before that had already completed 18 weeks of chemo, i didn't get clear margins so have had a further lumpectomy on the hope to get clear margins this time. If i do i will then go onto having a partial reconstruction (wouldn't have needed one if my first lumpectomy had been clear) followed by 15 radiotherapy treatments. But please remember everyone is different and everyone has different treatment plans. Have you thought of ringing your breast care nurse and asking her what the options are next. Mine have always been honest and helped when i have had questions i've needed answering. Good Luck on Monday, i was pleasantly surprised how easy the lumpectomy was, was sick due to the anesthetic the first op but was sent home same day with my second.  Please give me a shout of you think i can help at all xxx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy done

Posts.Content: Hello maxinem2 i haven't completely finished with all this poopy yet but i was told by my breast care nurse that they are available to me for 5 years from getting the all clear. So if i was you i would contact them and speak to them. They will be able to answer any questions you have and tell you if you should have seen your oncologist again or not.
Posts.Title: Two years since Chemo what now

Posts.Content: If it helps my tumor is/was 6cm and i had some in my lymph nodes too. I am currently having FEC-T chemo and the consultant has said this may be enough to get rid, if not the lump will be much smaller so less tissue will need to be removed if needs be.  Mine hasn't spread anywhere else xx
Posts.Title: Morning after diagnosis.....

Posts.Content: Good evening Bluebell22  We're all allowed to have down days, thank goodness, one thing about all this is it has a nasty habit of leaving us wondering whats what. No one can say its predictable.  Plus the SEs don't help they would put a downer on anyones day, i know the days i've felt poopy have been the days the SEs have been the worse. One chemo left and you've done it, make sure you give yourself a pat on the back because one thing we all know is even when the SEs are kind its still not something we'd chose to go through. Did you have your docetaxel first then your FEC?? I've done my 3 FEC and have my first of 3 docetaxel on Tuesday, any handy hints for the docetaxel? i will be finishing my chemo beginning of November. Not had any other scans since i started treatment but i do find myself sometimes feeling the lump and wondering if its shrunk or not.  Try to keep smiling you're nearly there
Posts.Title: Cheering Up

Posts.Content: Kaz18 i remember the feelings well, then i went to see my oncologist and as he looked at me he said, i can't see any problems with this one, i'll soon have you sorted. I left the room with a huge smile on my face filled with every confidence in him. What you have to remember is they do this every day, it is their job to look after us and make us better. You will feel better once you have you're treatment plan and you know whats coming.  Also remember you can do this and you will and we'll all be right by your side xxx
Posts.Title: MRI results & surgery / treatment plan tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hiya Guys is there room for a little one (well not so little but you know what i mean)  I will be starting my radiotherapy in Thursday, my daughters 25th birthday who is also pregnant with my first granddaughter on the 10th June, 7 days and counting. I can feel its going to be a bot of an emotional month after going through every treatment for almost a year.  But i have a weeks holiday booked for 2 days after my radiotherapy has finished, so trying to focus on that. I have already started using cream hoping it will prepare my poor boob, who has already been though so much, and so go as smoothly as possible. Best wishes to you all, and hints and tips would be greatly appreciated xx

Posts.Content: Just one more thing, and i say this from experience!!! DO NOT GOOGLE !!! People on here or your breast care nurse are the best people to ask if you want to know anything xxx

Posts.Title: Well Women now Reassure cancer Insurance. Anyone had a claim in recently...

Posts.Content: I think you need one of these first  You have done the best thing coming here the people here are fantastic and they will support and advise you every step of the way. I was diagnosed with the same as you back in July but i was 47, its S**t that anyone gets this but at 28 its even S**ter.  Being scared is natural but please believe me when i say that they know what they are doing and they will do whatever they need to do to get rid of this. Once you have a treatment plan you will feel better and once treatment starts as funny as it sounds it is a relief.  Please come and ask any questions you may want answering, there is always someone who has been where you are who can offer you support and advice. The people on here have helped me every step of the way. So rant, cry, scream, shout and sometimes we even laugh. You will find it easier speaking to people who totally get you.  There is a Breast cancer for under 50s group but it doesn't get as busy as this one,  Just make sure you keep talking to us, You are not alone and you will beat this xxxx lots of love to you xxxx
Posts.Title: Breast cancer at 28

Posts.Content: When i asked my consultant what stage and grade mine was he was reluctant to answer, mainly because of the google thing as he said there are many different tables of stages and grades around the world and that people sometimes look at a different table to what he uses and panic. Stage and grade are different. Stage is the size of the tumor and where it is. Grade is how it looks. Mine was stage 3 too, and hadn't spread to anywhere else, it was just one tumor in my boob and a trace in my lymph nodes. Once i'd finished my chemotherapy there were no cancer cells showing on my MRI. This DOES NOT mean you'll have chemotherapy, everyone's treatment plan is different and put together suit the you.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer at 28

Posts.Content: If you have any questions you want to ask him then write them down and take them with you. Just in case you forget what they are once you get in with him.  Good Luck with the fertility specialist and glad you are thinking past what is happening now.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer at 28

Posts.Content: We all have those fears, i know i do, my daughter is pregnant with my first grandchild and she is due in June, it scares me that i won't be around to see her grow up, but i have been told that once this is all over you think about it less. Also Mcmillan offer counselling if you think that might help. I also have fantastic breast care nurses who listen all the time and have already told me they will be around for the next 5 years and if i have any concerns or worries to ring them and they'll help me.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer at 28

Posts.Content: Hiya HR51 i also have TNBC and had FEC-T first. It worked really well. Are you having T (docetaxel) as well or just the FEC. The main side effects for me were feeling sick, but once you get use to when to take the anti sickness tablets you soon have it under control. My hair began to fall out 13 days after my first treatment but it only thinned out and i didn't need to shave my head until treatment 2. Saying that, just because i had those SEs doesn't mean you will, everyone is different. There is a monthly Chemo group which is good to be part of because then you can go through it with others and there are lots of people about with advice and support. If there is anything you want to know please give me a shout xx

Like i just said in another post cancer makes you paranoid, you've come this far and you can do this. Big Hugs for you and my fingers tightly crossed
Posts.Title: Lung nodule after ct scan

Posts.Content: Leolady56 We will all be here waiting for you when you feel it's time to come back. You are one very special lady and don't you ever forget that. You have made so many of my poopy times so much less poopy and i will be forever grateful for that.  Remember we are never very far away xxx
Posts.Title: Shout out to lovely Leolady56

Posts.Content: One of those silly questions i'm hoping someone can help me with. I am 7 weeks post chemo, but in the last couple of weeks i have felt like i have a constant lump in the back of my throat. Sorry if this sounds disgusting but its just phlegm and once its clear the lump goes but comes back within 5/10 minutes.  Its not painful but i can tell it's there all the time. I've also been burping alot. Wondered if it could have something to do with the lansoprazole i've been taking every day so stopped taking it but it hasn't made any difference.  Does anyone think it's anything to worry about or is it just one of those things i have to wait to go away on its own.  I am booked in for my lumpectomy on the 7th January and don't want it to delay it if it's something dodgy.
Posts.Title: Is it just after effects of chemo??

Posts.Content: When i was originally diagnosed i had BC in my lymph nodes, i had chemotherapy and i was told it had worked well, i then a lumpectomy and 3 lymph nodes removed.  They couldn't find the clip that was put in the nodes with signs of cancer so can't be sure if it was one of the 3 that had been removed or if it is still there. My surgeon wasn't concerned and said if i end up having radiotherapy they'll do radiotherapy on my arm pit but if i don't then they will just keep a check on it with mammograms. They will be doing the tests so they know what they are dealing with and what they need to do about it. So try not to worry too much till you know for sure whats going to happen xxx
Posts.Title: Two appointments now on Wednesday and Thursday for results?

Posts.Content: Trace_33 yep chemo all done and dusted. Had an MRI on Monday to see if the chemo had done it’s job just waiting for results and appointment with surgeon. Such a strange feeling now it’s over. Just waiting for my tongue and gums to make friends with the rest of my body then I’ll be near enough back to normal (whatever that means) and my hairs growing back
Posts.Title: Moving on from paclitaxol/carboplatin to EC chemo

Posts.Content: Hello Minty63 I had FEC-T chemotherapy then had a lumpectomy a couple of weeks ago, i will now move onto radiotherapy all being well with the results from the op.  I had mine the same 6 courses 3 weeks apart. 3 x FEC and 3 x Docetaxel. I'm not sure i ever read any of the information the hospital gave me. I started reading about chemotherapy and it scared me so i stopped reading it. What you have to remember is everyone is different, just because i had a side effect doesn't mean you will, everyone is different.  Try not to be scared, i broke all mine into parts, first part first chemo, and so one because if you look at it as 18 weeks it seems a lifetime, but by breaking it into parts it flew by. I look back now and think did that really happen to me. I didn't have a PICC line but i wish i had, when i went for my op a couple of weeks ago the anaesthetist commented on how much the chemo had knackered up my veins.  After i had finished my FEC-T the MRI showed no cancer cells, i could have finished there and then but i was told by my consultant that having a lumpectomy and radiotherapy will reduce the risk of it reoccuring, so while i'm at it i might as well have the full lot.  Main advice for your FEC is to make sure you take your anti- sickness medication even if you don't feel sick, i was only actually sick once and that was because i hadn't taken an anti sickness tablet soon enough. Want to know anything give me a shout will be more than happy to help make this easier for you.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer diagnosis and terrified of chemotherapy and radiotherapy...

Posts.Content: Hiya Trace_33 i had FEC which is the same as EC but with an extra drug. I can't compare it to pac/carbo as i had docetaxel with mine but i can tell you some of the side effects i had. The main side effect with the EC is nausea, luckily i was only actually sick once but felt sick the other times. You will be given anti sickness tablets make sure you take them even if you don't feel sick, they will keep it at bay. Also i lost my appetite so forgot to eat but because i forgot to eat i felt sick, vicious circle really. So i found eating little but often helped keep the sicky feelings at bay too. I also suffered terribly with heartburn,i was drinking gaviscon by the bottle but mentioned it to my chemo nurse who spoke to the pharmacist. He prescribed me lansoprazole it's amazing, from the day i started taking it i have had no more heartburn it also helped with the nausea. The way i described my cycle of EC was a poopy week, a not so poopy week and a good week.  Anything else you want to know just give me a shout more than happy to help x
Posts.Title: Moving on from paclitaxol/carboplatin to EC chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Beth  not much help to answering your questions I’ve only just been diagnosed and started chemo a few weeks ago.  I just wanted to say you are allowed down days, don’t be too tough on yourself, you have come this far so well done to you xx  The week after my first chemo I had a day where I thought “I’m not going to be able to do this” but here I am doing it !!  Have you rung your breast care centre maybe they’ll be able to help, although I’m sure there will be someone along here soon they’re a lovely bunch xx lots of love xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy discomfort and Scars

Posts.Content: Hiya RumCat sorry to find you here but its the best place to be when you find yourself in the situation you're in. I had a routine mammogram (early at 47 lucky for me) back in May this year. Was called back to be told i had a 6cm lump in my left boob and enlarged lymph nodes. One thing that has stuck with me is when i met my oncologist he looked at me and said "This is an easy one can't see no problems here"  I work at a special needs school and it was just before the summer holidays i was told it was cancer, i spoke to my oncologist and asked him if i could put my treatment off until the holidays started. This was around 3 weeks, he said not a problem. So mention it to your doctor and see what he says, have you thought of reducing the length of your holiday, so you can still go but for not as long? Like Leolady56 said, and you will see the longer you are here, that you can kick its butt, and you will. I had a holiday while i was having treatment so don't be thinking everything has to stop if the diagnosis is the one you don't want it to be. And as for boring us!!!! NO ONE bores anyone here, everyone listens and supports and gives out advice. So come rant, moan, cry and we even have a giggle sometimes.  Keep talking to us.

Posts.Title: Heart Pillow and Dammit Doll (HER Breast Friends)

Posts.Content: Hiya positivedad  Welcome to the community no one wants to be a member of, but in the circumstances is the best place to be. Can i be the bright spark to send the link Galligirl lol Chemo Chat Group there is a new chemo thread every month that people post in who are having chemo as ask for advice, you may also find someone going through the same as your wife which helps to know you're in it all together. There is also a  Family and Friends Group that you may find helpful for support for you.  Please remember everyone is different so just because someone has had a certain side effect it doesn't mean your wife will. Also try and take it each treatment at a time, and count it as one down and not how many left to go. Once i got started it found it went quicker than i thought.  Be sure that your wife takes the anti sickness tablets even if she doesn't feel sick and don't hesitate to ring the chemo unit if you have any concerns.  I found eating little and often helped, with feeling sick i didn't always fancy eating but by not eating i felt sick. So i made sure i had something even if i didn't fancy it. Just one other thing, no question is a silly one so come and ask us. I know i asked lots of silly questions and always found someone else was wondering the same or had experienced the same.

Posts.Title: Heart Pillow and Dammit Doll (HER Breast Friends)

Posts.Content: I had a mastectomy on Monday so have been in hospital for 5 days. On Tuesday my nurse brought in a carrier bag and said there are some gifts in there for you fro HER Breast Friends (Hull & East Riding Breast friends) they are a charity who make goodie bags for ladies with breast cancer. In the bag there was a pillow, a dammit doll, a gift bag and a folder with lots of support information and a Free voucher for 3 complementary therapies. Now those that know me know it doesn't take much to make me blub but this made me blub happy tears, to think a group of people had thought about ladies like me and put something together to make a difference. I just wanted to share them with you all.

Posts.Content: That's a good idea Horsing Around  i always keep after sun in the fridge so why i never thought of doing it with Aveeno i don't know xx
Posts.Title: Advice on which moisturiser to use during radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hello JayJerome and welcome to the club no one wants to be a member of. But when you find yourself in the situation we're all in or have been in its the best club going. All i can say is ask lots of questions, maybe write them down before you go for your appointment so you don't forget any. It can all be a bit of a blur but have faith in the people looking after you they do this every day. As for your treatment everyone is different. I had chemotherapy first on the hope it would shrink the tumor or get rid of it all together, on my MRI scan once my chemo had finished showed no cancer but i've still had a lumpectomy and will soon have radiotherapy. the lumpectomy and radiotherapy are belt and braces, to reduce the risk of it reoccuring.  I had my lumpectomy 18 days ago and haven't had any problems, would have only been in hospital for the day but was sick due to the anaesthetic, but was still only in for 24 hours. I will be having 15 zaps of radiotherapy over 3 weeks and been told that it only makes you tired.  Hope this helps a little bit if not sorry for waffling. Please continue to come here to rant, cry, for great support and we have even been known to have a laugh. Good Luck with everything x
Posts.Title: I am new here, newly diagnosed with DCIS....

Posts.Content: Hiya Cazza1234 go back to July and i was in the same position as you are today. My lump was 6 cm and some in my lymph nodes. I had a scan and it was nowhere else. Now fast forward to now, i have completed my chemotherapy 6 weeks ago and after a MRI scan there is NO cancer showing I will be having a lumpectomy in January and then radiotherapy these are to reduce the risk of it returning. So don't be thinking the worse xx  The best advice i can give you is take it one step at a time, and you are stronger than you know, you can and will kick this xx
Posts.Title: Not sure what I’m doing

Posts.Content: hello Shirley J do you have a phone number for the breast care nurses at the clinic you went to? If you do give them a ring and speak to them, they're great and will support you. As for a referral to a surgeon, my surgeon is also the breast care specialist so its possible that you have an appointment with them to talk about what they have found not necessarily for surgery.
Posts.Title: Confused!!

Posts.Content: Hiya Welshmakem first can i say well done on getting through the chemo, its no easy task but you've done it, you should be proud. I had chemotherapy then a lumpectomy with 3 lymph nodes removed. the lymph nodes came back clear but i didn't have clear margins from the lumpectomy. I went on to have a second lumpectomy to be told they had found a 5mm tumor and so went on to have a mastectomy. The reason i had the lumpectomies was because my nurse asked how would i feel if i had a mastectomy and was told there was only a small piece of cancer left and i had lost my whole breast because of it. Unfortunately i ended up having a mastectomy anyway but it was worth trying the lumpectomies first on the hope of saving my boob. In my opinion lumpectomies are a doddle compared to a mastectomy and if had got clear margins it would have definitely have been worth it. My cancer is triple negative and so supposedly harder to get rid of.I do think about the future but i have every faith in my consultant to do whatever he believes is best for me.
Posts.Title: Last chemo and approaching surgery

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear your news about your mum but like others have said don't automatically think the worse. The NHS is a wonderful thing as you will soon learn. Try not to worry about stuff you might not need to worry about, and being here is the best thing you have done. The people on here are amazing, they listen when your sad, they listen when your angry and believe it or not they make you smile and laugh too. Remember no question is a silly question, anything you need to know someone has either been there or are going through it and it is reassuring to know you're not alone. I have ranted on here when i've had a bad day and there is always someone around to cheer you up and tell you not to be so hard on yourself, it really is the best place to be for support.
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hiya roseenglish First can i welcome you to the group none of us wanted to join but it the best group to be in under the circumstances. I never felt my lump, i only found out because i had a mammogram when i was 47. We have all been where you are and totally get the not remembering, so next time you go if you have any questions write them down to ask once you get there. But the lady was right in what she said breast cancer is treatable, i know because i got the all clear last Tuesday. That doesn't help you now but i hope it does give you a bit of a piece of mind. You are doing the right thing with google, it is out of date and gives incorrect information. I read that my cancer was hard to get rid of, it filled me with dread and here i am with it all gone. So all that unnecessary worrying.  Keep talking to us, the people here give fantastic advice and support. Take Care xx
Posts.Title: recently diagnosed 2cm lesion possible 1 lymph node (Borderline)

Posts.Content: Hello Callib I have just notice you haven't had any responses to your question so by me posting it will pop it back up to the top. I can't help with your question as i had chemo to reduce the size of my lump before surgery but i am sure there will be someone around who will be able to help. Whatever you decide be sure its what you want to do. If you feel you are ready for the op then ask if you can have it. Don't feel pressured into doing something else because they have given you another option. I hated deciding for myself even told my consultant i didn't like it when he gave me choices and prefered it when he made the decisions. He still made me chose.  Or ring you're breast care nurse and speak to her, when i was given the choice between a lumpectomy and a mastectomy she didn't make the decision for me but she did ask me questions about things i hadn't thought of which helped me make a decision. Hopefully someone will be along soon with some advice.
Posts.Title: Neo adjuvant hormone therapy ( tamoxifen before surgery )

Posts.Content: Hiya Shirleyj So sorry to hear about your mum, i'm sure any doctor who knows your family history would be more than happy to send you for a mammogram even if it was just to put your mind at rest. My daughter found a lump, and mentioned it to me the week after i'd been diagnosed ioth BC, she was 23 at the time and the practice nurse she saw couldn't feel the lump but took her word for it and referred her to the Breast Care Team at the hospital she was seen within a week. When she got to the hospital they did a ultra sound scan and was told it was fibroadenoma. The nurse told her if she'd been 25 they would have given her a mammogram and taken a biopsy.  The Breast Care specialist told her that if ever she found any more or felt there was a change in the lump she has to ring them direct and she can go back and get checked out as often as necessary. So maybe if your doctor won't refer you to the Breast Care Clinic maybe contact then direct. The nurses there are amazing and i am sure they will help and support you all you need.
Posts.Title: My mom died at 43

Posts.Content: Hello Lou1234  Welcome to the site i have found this place a life saver, good days i can help others bad days people help me and its amazing there is always someone around saying yeah!! that happened to me. Also good for advice before you start your chemo etc, so you know what to expect and it makes it someone less scary. Financial help: I struggle too, i'm single so run my house myself, my hospital is a 60 mile round trip and my first worry was how am i going to afford to pay for petrol. So went to speak to the Macmillan lady at the hospital, because i don't get any benefits i was not entitled to any help from them. But since then i have contacted my Union and they have a welfare fund and may send me a donation to help me out with petrol costs, i was also told about a charity that is run in my village who will give help towards petrol costs. I am currently waiting to hear from them both, i didn't want to ask for help but as a friend said if i don't ask for it someone else will, i pay into my union every month so why shouldn't i get help from them. If you need a wig you may be able to get help with that too, if you go to patient services at the hospital they will help you out.  But back to this place remember no question is a silly question, its probably been asked before, if you're feeling sad tell us, if you want to rant then rant away and believe it or not this place will sometimes have you laughing. Take Care of yourself xx
Posts.Title: Hello, I’m new to this and would love a friendly hello

Posts.Content: Hiya lulupop i didn't think i would be able to do the injections either but as i live on my own i had no choice but to do them myself, i will tell you that not one of them hurt, even though i expected them to. I did like AnnJac and took the injection out of the fridge at least 30 minutes before as the nurse told me if you did it straight from the fridge it could sting. I was also told to do them just before bed as sometimes they can cause aches and pains but nothing major, because i did mine before i went to sleep i never had any. I was told i could have a district nurse come and do them but they wouldn't be able to give me a time so it would mean sitting in all day waiting.
Posts.Title: advice on giving injections after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Alice M All i can suggest is you ring your breast care nurse on Monday and ask her if she knows what they meant when they said it makes it more complicated. Don't take it that because they say its more complicated that the outcome will be any different it may be something like they need to change your treatment plan. I was told mine was going to be easy to get rid of but it had other ideas and it wasn't as plain sailing as first thought but i still got the all clear a couple of weeks ago. I say i took the scenic route instead of the motorway. As long as you get to the same destination then all's good. By me replying on here it will bump it back up to the top so hopefully someone else will be along with a reply soon, who knows better than me. But you should definitely ring your breast care nurse she might be able to put your mind at rest xx
Posts.Title: Sentinel node positive

Posts.Content: Not the same but i was diagnosed with BC and 3 weeks later i got  phone call to say another lump had been seen on my MRI, had ultrasound and 3 biopsies, i automatically thought well of course its another tumor because i already have one in that boob. Worried and worried and it turned out to be nothing. Try to keep positive, good luck today let us know how you get on xxxx
Posts.Title: New Lump

Posts.Content: Sorry Julesy1 can't help on the Tamoxifen front but just had to say love the title to your post, made me laugh out loud and i'm sat on my own
Posts.Title: Tamoxibollocks

Posts.Content: Congratulations and well done you xx Good luck and best wishes for the future xxxx
Posts.Title: Ringing the radiotherapy bell

Posts.Content: Sammystaff how lovely to see you, although wish it was under different circumstances. You've come so far and dealt with it so well, i'm sure anyone would be concerned but at least they have noticed and can sort it out. It's good that although she thinks its nothing to worry about that she isn't just ignoring it and asking others their opinion. I worry that now my chemo is over that something else will be found but i suppose thats what this thing does to us all. Keep strong and let us know what happens, Big Hugs for you xx
Posts.Title: Modules on the lung

Posts.Content: Devon Dumpling i had my last docetaxel 13 weeks ago, i had a trim just after christmas as it was very fluffy like baby hair, but i still have a good head full.
Posts.Title: Hair returning - but should I get excited?

Posts.Content: Good Afternoon couttleberry on my first docetaxel some more of my eyelashes fell out and some of my eye brows but none of the hair that was left on my head. But as i got close to my second they started growing back. To be honest my hair, eye brows and eyelashes have grown back a lot fast than i thought it would. I've even had a bit of a trim to get rid of the fluffy bits. I didn't have herceptin and perjeta so whether that will make a difference i don't know.
Posts.Title: Hair returning - but should I get excited?

Posts.Content: Hello Jsteph then this is the best place to be. I honestly can say this place has definitely made it easier, there are people i have met on here i will count as friends for life. No one gets what it's like unless they have been or are going through it. I met up with a friend at the end of last week who also had BC and we both commented on how many times people tell you how well you look but inside you feel really poopy. Talk to us, you have already had a reply from the amazing AnnJac who has just got me through one of the hardest weeks i've had so far, even though shes going through a tough time herself.  Don't feel ungrateful, feel glad you have people around you for the physical care and love, then come to us for the emotional stuff, Now i have finished chemo i don't seem to have as much attention from family and friends even though my last week was probably the hardest so far, but i have an amazing daughter and son who listen and get what i'm saying. Do you talk to your kids? i've been honest with mine from the start which i think has helped them cope with it better because they haven't been left to wonder whats going on. Its ok to have poopy days, no one can go through what we are and paint on a smile every day, so don't be so tough on yourself. Take each day as it comes, once you know you're treatment you will feel better because you'll know whats coming, but until them keep talking.  Big Hugs for you and don't ever be sorry for anything you post, thats why we are all here xxx
Posts.Title: Loneliness with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Morning CWS 2 scenarios i was called to breast care clinic after i had a routine mammogram at 47 to find out i had breast cancer, i didn't know i had a lump and felt no pain. My daughter then informed me that she'd had lots of pain in her boob and she could feel a lump, she went straight to the doctors who referred her immediately to the breast care clinic. She got an appointment within a week, she was told she has a Fibroadenoma. Because she is only 24 they didn't do a biopsy but said if she'd been 25 she would have had one.  What i'm trying to say is try not to worry until you know you have something to worry about. This place is great for support what ever your results are.  Let us know how you get on and good luck xx

Posts.Title: Breast Clinic Appointment Tomorrow Afternoon

Posts.Content: @lynn14 I've been there!! But finished my chemo last week. I think it's the unknown that scares you so get asking us questions and we might be able to put your mind at rest.  Do you know the name of the chemotherapy you're having? i can tell you there will be someone here who has had the same treatment or is still going through it and will be able to answer questions that will hopefully help you to settle a bit.  Use this place for ranting, crying and even laughing (it's not all doom and gloom) lots of people here to help you through this. You can and you will do this!!
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and chemo

Posts.Content: lynn14 i can help with the EC i had FEC which is the same but i had an extra drug. You'll have the pleasure of weeing pink lol and to be honest it is a bit yucky but if you take your anti sickness pills and eat often its doable. I didn't do the cold cap and my hair was my main concern and at the time upsetting but now its growing back i'm quite use to it. Have you thought about getting a wig?? they're amazing and i've had more people tell me they love my hair while wearing my wig than they ever did my real hair. You may also be able to get a voucher from the hospital to get help to buy one. There is a post called "Our wonderful wigs" on here i didn't want one till i saw some of the people on here with theirs and saw how fantastic they look. Would never guess they're wigs.
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and chemo

Posts.Content: lynn14 the aim is to get rid of the pink wee, my first FEC as the nurse pumped it into my veins she looked at me and said "This is what will get the B*****d" i did laugh, but it also what makes you feel sick, so she said drink lots to get it out your system quicker and side effects won't last as long. With FEC i use to say i had a poopy week, a not so poopy week then a good week lol  My hair is already growing back and i'm surprised how fast, i finished my chemotherapy last Tuesday. A lovely friend Maggie-Gaudigirl who i met on here sent me some info she'd been given last week. It said not to use baby shampoo but to use a anti-parabens shampoo daily. So i went out and bought some of that "Aussie" stuff and my hairs doing great   Looking good Leolady56 have you used any special shampoos or anything or just popped sea kelp?
